(Number of posts/thousands of United States dollars)

The overall increase of $0.7 million for the 14 continuing special political missions is attributable primarily to: (a) increased requirements for expert fees owing to the issuance of new fee ranges by the Office of Human Resources (OHR) (OHR/PG/2025/2); (b) higher estimates for common staff costs based on recent expenditure experience of staff entitlements; and (c) the application of lower vacancy rates for civilian personnel. The increase was offset in part by: (a) reduced requirements for telecommunications and network services owing to reduced provision of subscription to the emergency satellite communicator service and removal of the provision for satellite telephone data and video conference services based on utilization patterns; (b) the application of the latest reduced standard rate for communications and information technology (ICT) for New York; and (c) the proposed abolishment of two posts as part of the effort of the Security Council Subsidiary Organs Branch of Security Council Affairs Division to find efficiencies within its staffing levels. The resources reflect the expiration of mandate in October 2025 of the mission supporting the Implementation of Security Council resolution 2231 (2015), for which provision was made for 10 months in 2025.

The proposed vacancy rates applied in the budget take into account the experience to date. The assumptions considered for the proposed vacancy factors include the 12-month average vacancy rate in 2024 and the actual vacancy rate as at 31 March 2025. The lower of the two was used as the budgeted vacancy rate. This is in line with the policy guidance to improve the accuracy and consistency of the vacancy factors applied in the proposed budgets for 2026 and to ensure the proposed vacancy rates are based, as much as possible, on actual rates.
For the sake of brevity, the present document will include a section on extrabudgetary resources only for those missions that have projected extrabudgetary resources in 2025 or 2026.
II.	Cross-cutting information
Cooperation

To improve the effectiveness of sanctions imposed by the United Nations Security Council, the missions supporting Sanctions Committees will, as requested, engage with the Informal Working Group of the Security Council on General United Nations Security Council Sanctions Issues established by resolution 2744 (2024).
Gender perspective

Special political missions are guided by the relevant Security Council resolutions on the women and peace and security agenda, which mandate the incorporation of a gender perspective into the political work of the United Nations, including in special political missions. The missions are also guided by General Assembly resolution 75/100 on the comprehensive review of special political missions, in which the Assembly reaffirmed the important role of women in the prevention and resolution of conflicts and in peacebuilding and recognized the importance of the equal and effective participation and the full involvement of women at all levels, at all stages and in all aspects of the peaceful settlement of disputes, conflict prevention and conflict resolution.

The sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, along with the mission supporting the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006), integrate a gender perspective into their operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, and as guided by the relevant Security Council resolutions. Gender balance is taken into consideration in the recruitment and rostering of experts, the Focal Point for Delisting and the Ombudsperson, as well in the recruitment of related staff. The terms of reference for experts in sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels indicate that experts are to incorporate gender perspectives into their substantive areas of responsibility. In addition, the Focal Point for Delisting will be examining delisting petitions in relation to relevant designation criteria, which may refer to sexual and gender-based violence. These missions are also guided by the gender strategy of the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, including in the provision of available gender training to staff and sanctions-specific gender training to all experts. To further diversify the geographical and gender composition of sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, the Department participated, in October 2024, alongside other UN Secretariat entities, in the ImpactPool virtual career fair for Women in Senior Roles, hosted by a career web platform specializing in humanitarian and international jobs. A total of 2,343 women registered for the career fair, of whom 459 (from countries across all regional groups) visited the joint UN Secretariat’s virtual booth containing presentations, fact sheets, videos and information on job openings for sanctions experts. In addition, in May and June 2024, the Department briefed representatives of the Group of African States, the Group of Arab States, the Group of Eastern European States, and the Group of Latin America and the Caribbean States on the recruitment process of members of sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels.
Disability inclusion

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, special political missions review the Strategy with a view to further advancing disability inclusion through inclusive messaging, awareness-raising and promoting the Strategy through their work, including in political and peace processes. The missions also support mitigating measures to overcome accessibility challenges, in addition to the efforts by relevant United Nations entities to ensure the accessibility of facilities, platforms, security and other infrastructure to facilitate easy access and use by persons with disabilities.
Evaluation activities

The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs will support the biennial assessment by the Office of Internal Oversight Services on strengthening the role of evaluation and the application of evaluation findings on programme design, delivery and policy directives. Mission-specific evaluation activities are described, as applicable, under the specific missions in the present report.
III.	Special political missions

text: 1.	Group of Experts on the Democratic Republic of the Congo

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Group of Experts on the Democratic Republic of the Congo is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the arms embargo, asset freeze, travel ban and transport and customs measures, as well as for providing information relevant to the potential designation of individuals and entities. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant Security Council resolutions, including resolution 1533 (2004), and renewed in its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2738 (2024). The sanctions regime is aimed at preventing individuals and entities from undermining the peace, stability or security of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning the Democratic Republic of the Congo, which includes an arms embargo on all non-governmental entities and individuals operating in the territory of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, an asset freeze and a travel ban.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Group of Experts will provide updated information to the Security Council and the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1533 (2004) concerning the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission cooperates with, among others, Member States and the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region to request information relevant to its investigations into the implementation and/or violations of the sanctions regime concerning the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Group of Experts cooperates with, among others, the United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from the Committee’s sanctions list, the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict, the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General on Sexual Violence in Conflict and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Group of Experts cooperates with the Mission, the Department of Safety and Security and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Group of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Group of Experts to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced understanding by the Security Council and the Committee of the illegal exploitation of natural resources and the activities of armed groups in the Democratic Republic of the Congo

The Group of Experts reported on the activities of armed groups and criminal networks in destabilizing the Democratic Republic of the Congo through the illegal exploitation or trade in natural resources. The Group of Experts recommended that neighbouring States investigate and prosecute individuals and criminal networks involved in the smuggling of minerals and that Member States raise awareness among relevant actors of the need to enforce mineral supply chain due diligence guidelines.

The above-mentioned work contributed to the Security Council and the Committee receiving updated information on the involvement of armed groups and criminal networks in the illicit exploitation of and trade in natural resources.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 3).
Table 3 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee continued to receive updated information on the illicit exploitation of or trafficking in natural resources and considered adjusting the designations of individuals and/or entities
Security Council and Committee received updated information on the illicit exploitation of or trafficking in natural resources and considered amendments to the list entries, and new designations
Security Council and Committee continued to receive updated information on the illicit exploitation of or trafficking in natural resources and approved new designations

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced understanding by the Security Council and the Committee of the illegal activities of armed groups in the Democratic Republic of the Congo – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the work of the Group of Experts contributed to the full implementation of the sanctions regime, which met the planned target. The Group of Experts reported on the involvement of individuals and entities in destabilizing activities in the Democratic Republic of the Congo through the illicit exploitation and trafficking in natural resources. The Committee added six individuals to its sanctions list for having engaged in or provided support for acts that undermined the peace, stability or security of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Lessons learned and planned change

In view of the limited awareness by relevant stakeholders of the sanctions measures, the lesson for the Group of Experts was the need to strengthen consultations and outreach activities with Member States and relevant stakeholders. In applying the lesson, the mission will continue to engage with regional Member States and support the Committee’s outreach efforts.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 4).
Table 4 – Performance measure

Human resources

The proposed resource requirements for the Group of Experts for 2026 amount to $1,417,500 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for the salaries and common staff costs ($239,900) for the continuation of two posts (P-3) to provide substantive, administrative and security support in relation to the sanctions regime, and operational costs ($1,231,600) comprising expert fees ($802,900) and travel ($264,600) of the six experts, official travel of staff ($24,000) and other operational and logistical support requirements, including the rental of premises, rental of vehicles, communications and information technology services and other supplies, services and equipment ($140,100).
For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and level of posts for the mission. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied to the staff costs on the basis of the average vacancy rate in 2024.

The decrease in the requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to lower requirements for civilian personnel owing to the application of a higher vacancy rate compared with the rate of 16.7 per cent applied in 2025. The decrease is offset in part by increased requirements for expert fees.

text: 2.	Panel of Experts on the Sudan

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts on the Sudan is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the arms embargo, asset freeze and travel ban, as well as for providing information relevant to the potential designation of individuals and entities. The mandate is defined in Security Council resolution 1591 (2005), and renewed in its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2772 (2025). The sanctions regime is one of the tools used by the Council to address the conflict in Darfur and is aimed at preventing threats to the stability in Darfur and the region, towards a peaceful settlement of the conflict in Darfur. In its resolution 2772 (2025), the Council extended the mandate of the Mission until 12 March 2026.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning the Sudan, which includes an arms embargo, an asset freeze and a travel ban, as well as to report on the possible threats to the peace and stability of Darfur, including the current conflict.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will provide updated information to the Security Council and the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1591 (2005) concerning the Sudan.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the Sudan sanctions regime.
With regard to cooperation with other entities, the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, Member States and the African Union.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from the Committee’s sanctions list, the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, the United Nations Children’s Fund and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Panel cooperates with the Department of Safety and Security, UNDP and the World Food Programme (WFP).
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Committee received updated information on Darfuri armed groups in Darfur and Libya and on the impact of the wider conflict in the Sudan on Darfur

In 2024, the Panel of Experts reported on the strategies employed by the Rapid Support Forces to consolidate its control over Darfur, which included targeted attacks on internally displaced persons and widespread acts of conflict-related sexual violence. The Panel also reported on the Sudan Armed Forces’ presence being limited to isolated strongholds such as El Fasher, and their reliance on indiscriminate and widespread airstrikes. The Panel observed that cross-border recruitment and mobilization of transnational communities fuelled insecurity in Chad, Libya and South Sudan.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 8).
Table 8 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee received updated information on Darfuri armed groups in Darfur and Libya, their financing and their integration in accordance with the Juba Peace Agreement
Security Council and Committee received updated information on Darfuri armed groups in Darfur and Libya, their financing and their integration in accordance with the Juba Peace Agreement
Security Council and Committee received updated information on Darfuri armed groups in Darfur and Libya, their financing and their integration in accordance with the Juba Peace Agreement

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Updated information on the ongoing conflict in Darfur and its impact on the wider region – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the work of the Panel contributed to the full implementation of the sanctions regime, which met the planned target. The information provided by the Panel enhanced the Security Council’s and the Committee’s understanding of the Darfuri armed groups’ activities in Darfur and Libya, as well as of possible threats to the peace and stability of Darfur and the impact of the wider conflict in the Sudan on Darfur.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was the continued need to adapt its investigation methods owing to the security situation in the Sudan. While the Panel has been unable to travel to Darfur since the outbreak of the conflict, it benefited from its two visits to Port Sudan, the Sudan, and met Darfuri refugees in Chad, Kenya and Uganda. In applying the lesson, the Panel will continue using its contacts to advance investigations and will report on the conflict, on peace initiatives to stop the conflict in Darfur, and on its impact on the wider region.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 9).
Table 9 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee received reporting from the Panel of Experts on activities of Darfuri armed groups in Libya and the Sudan
Security Council and Committee received updated information on the Darfuri armed groups in Darfur and Libya and their integration

text: 3.	Support to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006)

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006) oversees the implementation of the sanctions regime concerning the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea. The sanctions regime is the most comprehensive and complex of all United Nations sanctions regimes in effect and aims to ensure that the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea abandons all nuclear weapons and its existing nuclear programme, as well as any other existing weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missile programmes, in a complete, verifiable and irreversible manner. The regime includes 26 sanctions measures. In addition to an arms embargo and an embargo relating to nuclear, ballistic missile and other weapons of mass destruction programmes, a travel ban and/or asset freeze on designated individuals and entities, it includes a range of maritime provisions for designating vessels for involvement in prohibited activities and restrictions on various commodity transfers, such as refined petroleum products, minerals, metals, heavy machinery, transportation vehicles, luxury goods, seafood, textiles and more. It also includes restrictions on transportation and on financial services, as well as on overseas workers. Furthermore, to ensure that the measures that it imposed do not have adverse humanitarian consequences for the civilian population, the Security Council adopted a wide range of humanitarian and other exemptions.

The support of the Secretariat is required in all areas of the Committee’s mandate, including in specific areas in which the Secretariat has been mandated by the Security Council. Member States and other actors liaise directly with the Committee and the Secretariat for guidance on or assistance in implementing provisions of relevant resolutions. The Committee and the Secretariat receive a high volume of information on alleged violations of the sanctions measures, which were previously handled by the Panel of Experts. In addition, the Chair and the Committee may undertake increased outreach activities to promote better understanding and implementation of the relevant resolutions, including of the various exemptions processes. Moreover, the reopening of the borders of the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea resulting in the ongoing and anticipated return of the international community and of the UN country team into the country, is expected to lead to an increase in humanitarian and other exemptions and guidance requests to and from the Committee.

Furthermore, the Secretariat assists in responding to guidance and information requests from Member States, relevant international organizations and other entities on the various sanctions measures and their exemptions, which had previously been handled by the Panel.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, which includes an arms embargo, an embargo relating to nuclear, ballistic missile and other weapons of mass destruction programmes, an asset freeze, a travel ban, maritime and financial measures, a ban on petroleum products and crude oil, a coal ban and sanctions measures in other sectoral areas.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the mission will continue to support the work of the Security Council and the Committee in relation to the implementation of the sanctions regime with regard to the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea.

The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee conducive to overseeing and promoting the full implementation of the Council sanctions measures.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission will continue to cooperate with the resident coordinator’s office and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and other United Nations agencies carrying out humanitarian assistance and relief activities in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, including the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, UNDP, the United Nations Population Fund, the United Nations Children’s Fund, WFP and the World Health Organization, as well as other non-United Nations agencies carrying out related activities. The Mission will continue to facilitate the work of the UN agencies through regular and ad hoc briefings to the UN country team in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea. The mission will also continue to cooperate with other United Nations and non-United Nations entities carrying out activities involving the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea in guiding them through the intricate sanctions measures and exemption procedures to ensure sanctions compliance. In the context of safety and security, information technology security and logistics, the mission cooperates with the Department of Safety and Security and the Office of Information and Communications Technology.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States will comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and continue to cooperate with the sanctions committee;
(b)	The Chair and the Committee are adequately supported to perform their functions as mandated by the Security Council.
Programme performance in 2024 – Committee continues to carry out its work on overseeing sanctions implementation

In 2024, the mission supported the Committee as it continued to oversee sanctions implementation and ensured the Committee continued to receive relevant information. The mission organized additional briefings to facilitate the exchange of views with relevant actors, including the United Nations Office for Disarmament Affairs, United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime and the Financial Action Task Force.

The above-mentioned work contributed to the Council’s and the Committee’s ability to oversee the implementation of sanctions as the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea persisted in carrying out prohibited activities, including ballistic missile launches.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 13).
Table 13 – Performance measure

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Maintaining the continuous support to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006) – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission’s work contributed to promoting an understanding of the complex sanctions regime and the Committee’s work  which met the planned target. The mission assisted the Security Council, the Committee, Member States and other stakeholders and facilitated the oversight of the implementation of the sanctions measures.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the mission was the need to ensure the Committee has continued access to adequate information to enhance its understanding of sanctions implementation in the absence of a monitoring mechanism, especially given the breadth of the sanctions measures and the scope of potential actors. It was also important to raise awareness of the sanctions measures and promote compliance by encouraging Member States to report on their national implementation of the sanctions measures and responding to requests for guidance from various sanctions implementation partners, including Member States, and UN and other humanitarian actors. In applying the lesson, the mission will strengthen its outreach activities by engaging Member States and other stakeholders. This will be achieved, inter alia, through open and regional group briefings, special meetings on important thematic and regional topics and implementation challenges faced by Member States.

A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts on Libya is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the arms embargo, asset freeze, travel ban and measures in relation to attempts to illicitly export petroleum, and for providing information relevant to the potential designation of individuals and entities. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant Security Council resolutions, including resolutions 1973 (2011), 2009 (2011) and 2017 (2011), and renewed by its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2769 (2025). The sanctions regime is aimed at preventing and containing threats to the peace, security and stability of Libya, including obstructing or undermining the successful completion of the political transition. In its resolution 2733 (2024), the Council requested the Secretary-General to report on the implementation of the arms embargo on the high seas off the coast of Libya within 6 months and 11 months of the adoption of the resolution. The Secretary-General submitted his first report on 26 November 2024 (S/2024/858), while the second report was submitted on 25 April 2025 (S/2025/257).

In its resolution 2769 (2025), the Security Council decided to allow the frozen cash reserves of the Libyan Investment Authority (LIA) to be invested in low-risk time deposits and in fixed financial instruments, subject to a notification and approval procedure by the Sanctions Committee concerning Libya, and requested the Panel of Experts to assess the effect and performance of these investments in their annual final reports.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Libya, which includes an arms embargo, an asset freeze, a travel ban and measures in relation to attempts to illicitly export petroleum.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will provide updated information to the Security Council and to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1970 (2011) concerning Libya, including an assessment of the performance of reinvestment of the LIA’s frozen cash reserves.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in the context of information-sharing, the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, Member States and the European Union, in particular its military operation in the Mediterranean.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts cooperates with the United Nations Support Mission in Libya, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from the Committee’s sanctions list, and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Panel cooperates with the Department of Safety and Security and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions in the field.
(c) 	Proposals for investment and reinvestment of LIA’s frozen cash reserves are submitted.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to address violations of the arms embargo

In its final report (S/2024/914), the Panel of Experts highlighted the unprecedented influence of armed groups over State institutions in western and eastern Libya. The Panel further recommended possible actions that could enable the reinvestment of the LIA’s frozen assets as requested by the Council. The Panel also reported on continued violations of the arms embargo, on illicit fuel smuggling by armed groups, and on human trafficking and migrant smuggling through Libyan territory involving Libyan armed actors. The Panel recommended clarifying the scope of the arms embargo and that additional individuals who met the sanctions designation criteria be considered for listing.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18).
Table 18 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee continued to receive information on instances of non-compliance with the arms embargo and considered follow-up action to address violations of the arms embargo

Security Council and Committee received information on instances of non-compliance with the assets freeze and the arms embargo, and on the possibility of reinvestment of the LIA’s frozen assets, and considered follow-up action

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to address non-compliance with the assets freeze and the arms embargo – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the work of the Panel contributed to the implementation of this sanctions regime, meeting the planned target. The Panel reported on unprecedented levels of influence over State institutions exercised by armed groups in Libya, international human trafficking and smuggling networks which utilized Libyan territory as a transit hub, on the violations of international humanitarian and human rights law, terrorist elements active in southern Libya, and on possible reinvestment of the LIA’s frozen assets. This enabled the Security Council and the Committee to consider follow-up action.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was the need for improved coordination and information-sharing with the Government of Libya, relevant international bodies and regional actors. In applying the lesson, the Panel will continue to enhance information exchange and improve cooperation among relevant stakeholders.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 19).

The increase in the requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to higher requirements for civilian personnel, owing to the application of a lower vacancy rate for international staff compared with the rate of 45.8 per cent applied in 2025 and higher estimates for common staff costs, as well as increased requirements for expert fees. The increase is offset in part by lower requirements for telecommunications and network services and the application of latest ICT standard rates.

text: 5.	Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2745 (2024)

children.text: A.	 Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2745 (2024) is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the targeted arms embargo, asset freeze and travel ban, as well as for providing information relevant to the potential designation of individuals and entities. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant Security Council resolutions, including resolution 2127 (2013), and renewed in its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2745 (2024), by which the Council changed the name of the Panel of Experts on the Central African Republic to the Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2745 (2024) and decided to lift the arms embargo on the Government of Central African Republic and to continue to apply the arms embargo to armed groups and associated individuals operating in the Central African Republic. The sanctions regime is aimed at preventing individuals and entities from undermining the peace, stability or security of the Central African Republic.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the 2745 sanctions regime, which includes a targeted arms embargo that no longer applies to the Government of the Central African Republic, as well as an asset freeze and a travel ban.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will continue to provide updated information to the Security Council and the Security Council Committee pursuant to resolution .

The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime, in particular by non-governmental entities and individuals providing support to armed groups or criminal networks through the illicit exploitation of or trade in natural resources, including diamonds, gold, wildlife and wildlife products in or from the Central African Republic.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in the context of information-sharing the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, Member States, the African Union, the European Union Common Security and Defence Policy Advisory Mission in the Central African Republic, the Economic Community of Central African States, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region and the Central African Economic and Monetary Community.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from the Committee’s sanctions list, the United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research, the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict, the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General on Sexual Violence in Conflict and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Panel cooperates with the Department of Safety and Security and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced understanding by the Security Council and the Committee of the illicit activities of armed groups

The Panel of Experts reported on the increased involvement of armed group elements in mercenary activities in the Sudan, which has become their significant source of financing. In particular, the leaders of those armed groups active in the eastern Central African Republic have been instrumental in coordinating and leasing their personnel as mercenaries. Additionally, the Panel of Experts reported on an increase in the use of advanced improvised explosive devices in targeted attacks on bases of the Central African Armed Forces and of foreign forces.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 23).
Table 23 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee had relevant information on the illicit exploitation of and trafficking in natural resources and arms embargo violations, and acted on Panel of Experts recommendations
Security Council and Committee had relevant information on the illicit exploitation of and trafficking in natural resources and arms embargo violations
Security Council and Committee had relevant information on the illicit exploitation of and trafficking in natural resources and arms embargo violations

children.text: Planned result for 2026

Better understanding by the Security Council and the Committee of the illicit exploitation of and trafficking in natural resources and sexual violence in conflict – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The work of the Panel contributed to the full implementation of the sanctions regime, which met the planned target. The Panel recommended to the Committee to designate individuals involved in sexual and gender-based violence, arms trafficking and incitement to violence based on previous statements of case provided by the Panel. The Panel also documented arms embargo violations involving the use of advanced improvised explosive devices in targeted attacks by armed groups.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was to continue to enhance the collection and validation of information for its reports, given the limited access to some individuals, facilities and areas in the Central African Republic. In applying this lesson, the Panel will continue to use information, databases and subscriptions procured by the United Nations, including the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 24).
Table 24 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee received comprehensive information on the illicit exploitation of and trafficking in natural resources, with recommendations for action
Security Council and Committee had relevant information on the illicit exploitation of and trafficking in natural resources and acted on the Panel’s recommendations

Security Council and Committee receive further updated relevant information on the illicit exploitation of and trafficking in natural resources and sexual violence in conflict, and consider designating individuals and entities
Security Council and Committee receive further relevant information on the illicit activities of the armed groups, including arms trafficking

The proposed resource requirements for the Panel of Experts for 2026 amount to $1,356,700 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($336,600) for the continuation of two posts (1 P-3 and 1 General Service (Other level)) to provide substantive, administrative and security support in relation to the sanctions regime, and operational costs ($1,020,100) comprising expert fees ($642,800) and travel ($248,500) of the five experts, official travel of staff ($33,200) and other operational and logistical support requirements, including the rental of premises, rental of vehicles, communications and information technology services and other supplies, services and equipment ($95,600).

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and level of posts for the mission. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the staff costs for both international and national staff on the basis of the average vacancy rate in 2024.

The increase in the requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to increased requirements for expert fees, and higher estimates for common staff costs. The increase is offset in part by the reduced provision for rental of vehicles, lower requirements for telecommunications and network services and the application of latest ICT standard rates.
A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts on Yemen is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the asset freeze, travel ban and targeted arms embargo on designated individuals and entities, as well as for providing information relevant to the potential designation of such individuals and entities. The mandate is defined in Security Council resolution 2140 (2014), as modified in resolution 2216 (2015) and extended, most recently, in resolution 2758 (2024). The sanctions regime is aimed at preventing and containing threats to the peace, security and stability of Yemen.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Yemen, which includes a targeted arms embargo, an asset freeze and a travel ban.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will provide updated information to the Security Council and the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 2140 (2014).
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in the context of information-sharing the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, Member States, the Combined Maritime Forces and the International Criminal Police Organization (INTERPOL).

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from the Committee’s sanctions list, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, WFP, the United Nations Verification and Inspection Mechanism for Yemen and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Panel cooperates with the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen, the Department of Safety and Security and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Further enhanced awareness of the trafficking in arms and materiel for use in certain military applications

In 2024, the Panel reported the Houthis had received weapons, training, technical assistance and financial support from various actors, including a regional country and from armed groups active in several regional countries. The Panel provided detailed information on the diverse military materiel and technology acquired by the Houthis via illegal transfers by land and sea, including components of complex weapons and electro-optical surveillance systems, and small arms and light weapons.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 28).
Table 28 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee awareness of the use of commercially available civilian components in some military applications in Yemen resulted in enhanced vigilance with regard to the export of such items
Security Council and Committee received comprehensive information from the Panel of Experts on the trafficking of arms and related materiel

Security Council and Committee received comprehensive information from the Panel of Experts on the trafficking of arms and related materiel, including sources, types and scale of violations of the arms embargo

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Further enhanced awareness of the trafficking in arms and commercial components for use in certain military applications – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the work of the Panel contributed to the full implementation of the sanctions regime, which met the planned target. The Panel reported on potential smuggling activities between the Houthis and Al-Shabaab in Somalia. The Panel will continue to provide information on the trafficking in arms and dual-use materiel which could be adapted for military application.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was the need to further enhance information collection on arms and related material used by the Houthis and their potential cooperation with Al-Shabaab. In applying the lesson, the Panel will continue to engage with Member States and relevant stakeholders to conduct inspections, collect data and use databases and subscriptions procured by the United Nations to strengthen its analysis.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 29).
Table 29 – Performance measure

The increase is offset in part by lower requirements in the telecommunications and network services and the application of latest OICT standard rates.

text: 7.	Panel of Experts on South Sudan

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts on South Sudan is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the arms embargo, asset freeze and travel ban, as well as for providing information relevant to the potential designation of individuals and entities. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant Security Council resolutions, including resolution 2206 (2015), and renewed in its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2731 (2024). The sanctions regime is aimed at, but not limited to, targeting spoilers of the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan, which was signed on 12 September 2018. On 15 April 2025, following a request by the Council in its resolution 2731 (2024), the Secretary-General provided the Council with an assessment of the progress achieved on the key benchmarks established in resolution 2577 (2021) (S/2025/231).
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning South Sudan, which includes a territorial arms embargo, an asset freeze and a travel ban.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will provide updated information, including on the potential impacts of elections currently scheduled for December 2026 on the overall situation in South Sudan, to the Security Council and the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 2206 (2015) concerning South Sudan.

The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime, including actions or policies that have the purpose of impeding the conduct or legitimacy of free and fair elections in South Sudan.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in the context of information-sharing the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, Member States, the African Union and the Intergovernmental Authority on Development.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts cooperates with the United Nations Mission in South Sudan, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from the Committee’s sanctions list, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict, the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General on Sexual Violence in Conflict and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety and security, information technology security and logistics, the Panel cooperates with the Mission, the Department of Safety and Security and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Committee members receive an update on the implementation of the Revitalized Agreement and on the progress of implementation of the arms embargo key benchmarks

The Panel of Experts provided the Security Council and the Committee with information on progress, and the lack thereof, in implementing the Revitalized Agreement, focusing on transitional security arrangements and preparations for South Sudan’s first election since its independence, planned for December 2024. That information was timely, as the elections were meant to mark a significant milestone in the country’s transitional period, while the implementation of the transitional security arrangements was seen as crucial for ensuring the successful organization of the elections.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 33).
Table 33 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee received updated information on the progress of implementation of the Revitalized Agreement and the benchmarks for the adjustment of the arms embargo

Security Council and Committee received updated information on the progress of implementation of the Revitalized Agreement and reviewed the arms embargo based on the progress achieved on the key benchmarks

Security Council and Committee received updated information on the progress of implementation of the Revitalized Agreement and reviewed the arms embargo based on the progress achieved on the key benchmarks

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Update on the implementation of the Revitalized Agreement and on the progress of implementation of the arms embargo key benchmarks – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the work of the Panel contributed to the full implementation of the sanctions regime, which met the planned target. The Panel’s reporting deepened the Committee’s understanding of progress and challenges in the implementation of the Revitalized Agreement. It also contributed to the Security Council’s decision in resolution 2731 (2024) to maintain the arms embargo. The Council also reiterated its readiness to review the arms embargo measures, based on the progress achieved on the key benchmarks.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was the continued need to enhance the collection and validation of information for its reports, given the limited access to some individuals, facilities and areas in South Sudan owing to the security situation. In applying the lesson, the Panel will continue to use relevant communication technologies, databases and subscriptions provided by the United Nations, and corroborate information with confidential sources in locations accessible to the Panel, including outside of South Sudan.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 34).
Table 34 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee received information on the progress achieved on the established key benchmarks and considered the review of the arms embargo
Security Council and Committee reviewed the arms embargo on the basis of updated information regarding progress achieved on the established key benchmarks
Security Council and Committee further reviewed the arms embargo based on updated information regarding progress in implementing the Revitalized Agreement and the established key benchmarks

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and level of posts for the mission. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the staff costs for both international and national staff on the basis of the average vacancy rate in 2024.

text: 8.	Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team pursuant to resolutions 1526 (2004) and 2253 (2015) concerning Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Da’esh), Al-Qaida and the Taliban and associated individuals and entities

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team, which supports the work of both the Security Council Committee pursuant to resolutions 1267 (1999), 1989 (2011) and 2253 (2015) concerning Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Da’esh), Al-Qaida and associated individuals, groups, undertakings and entities (the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee), and the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1988 (2011), is responsible for assisting in and reporting on the implementation of the asset freezes, travel bans and targeted arms embargoes on designated individuals and entities. The mandate is derived from the priorities established in the relevant Council resolutions, including resolution 1267 (1999), and renewed in its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2734 (2024), 2761 (2024) and 2763 (2024). The sanctions regimes are aimed at strengthening the Council’s response to threats to international peace and security caused by terrorist acts and at contributing to the peace, stability and security of Afghanistan.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of sanctions regimes concerning ISIL (Da’esh), Al-Qaida and the Taliban, which include targeted arms embargoes, asset freezes and travel bans.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Monitoring Team will provide updated information to the Security Council, the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee, and the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1988 (2011).
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Council and the Committees to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regimes.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in the context of information-sharing the Monitoring Team cooperates with, among others, Member States, the International Air Transport Association, the International Civil Aviation Organization, the World Customs Organization, the Financial Action Task Force and INTERPOL.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Monitoring Team cooperates with, among others, the Counter-Terrorism Committee Executive Directorate, the Office of Counter-Terrorism, the mission assisting the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004), the Office of the Ombudsperson established pursuant to Security Council resolution 1904 (2009), the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ exemptions requests, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA), and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety and security, information technology security and logistics, the Monitoring Team cooperates with the Department of Safety and Security, the Office of Information and Communications Technology, United Nations field missions and UNDP, as appropriate.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Monitoring Team;
(b)	The security situation allows the Monitoring Team to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced analysis to follow an evolving threat

To assist in addressing the global terrorism threat posed by ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida and the threat posed by the Taliban to the peace, stability and security of Afghanistan, and to fully implement sanctions measures, the Monitoring Team submitted nine reports to the Security Council or the Committees in 2024, providing analysis on evolving global terrorism threat, and two reports on the situation in Afghanistan. The Monitoring Team gathered information from Member States, including the de facto authorities in Afghanistan, regional organizations, and other stakeholders, and used databases and subscriptions procured by the United Nations to conduct research.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 38).
Table 38 – Performance measure

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Strengthened analysis to follow an evolving threat – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

Through its engagement with Member States and with other stakeholders, the Monitoring Team met the planned target. In 2024, the Committees considered new designations and removed one individual from the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida sanctions list. The Committee also approved amendments to the entries of 6 individuals and 1 entity on the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida sanctions list. In 2024, the Committees also approved exemptions from existing sanctions measures.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Monitoring Team was the continued need to seek efficiencies in planning in-person meetings with Member States, regional organizations, and other stakeholders to gather sensitive and confidential information and to provide tailored training to Member States on sanctions implementation. In applying the lesson, the Monitoring Team will continue to optimize its visits, regional meetings and participation in multilateral meetings to sustain in-person confidential discussions with Member States, regional organizations, and other stakeholders. The Monitoring Team will continue to hold virtual meetings using communication technology and benefit from databases and subscriptions procured by the United Nations for research.

The proposed resource requirements for the Monitoring Team for 2026 amount to $6,003,300 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($2,652,400) for the continuation of 17 posts (1 P-5, 4 P-4, 6 P-3 and 6 General Service (Other level)) to provide substantive and administrative support to the sanctions regimes, and operational costs ($3,350,900) comprising expert fees ($2,178,100) and travel of experts ($401,700), official travel of staff ($89,200) and other operational and logistical support requirements, including the rental of premises, communications and information technology services and other supplies, services and equipment ($618,900).

For 2026, the following changes are proposed to the number and level of posts for the mission, reflecting efforts to enhance operational efficiency and streamline functions through consolidation and the improved use of technology:
(a)	Abolishment of one Administrative Assistant (General Service (Other level)) staff in New York, by leveraging digital tools and redistributing functions to avoid duplication; and

(b)	Abolishment of one Administrative Assistant (General Service (Other Level)) staff in New York, by consolidating for a more integrated and flexible allocation of human resources, while maintaining service delivery standards.

A vacancy rate of 14.4 per cent has been applied to the staff costs for international staff, while a rate of 38.5 per cent has been applied for national staff, both on the basis of the average vacancy rate in 2024.

The decrease in the requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to: (a) the abolishment of two General Service posts and the associate operational provisions; (b) the application of a higher vacancy rate for national staff compared to 2025; (c) lower requirements for telecommunications and network services; (d) the application of latest ICT standard rates; and (e) the discontinuation of the subscription to the BBC Monitoring Service as cost avoidance as comparable content is accessible through an alternative subscription already available to the Monitoring Team. The decrease is offset in part by increased requirements for expert fees and the application of a lower vacancy rate for international staff compared with the rate of 17.5 per cent applied in 2025.

text: 9.	Office of the Ombudsperson established pursuant to Security Council resolution 1904 (2009)

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Office of the Ombudsperson to the Security Council Committee pursuant to resolutions 1267 (1999), 1989 (2011) and 2253 (2015) concerning Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Da’esh), Al-Qaida and associated individuals, groups, undertakings and entities is responsible for reviewing delisting requests from individuals or entities inscribed on the related sanctions list. The mandate is defined in Council resolution 1904 (2009), and it was renewed in its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2734 (2024).
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to provide an independent review of delisting requests of individuals, entities and undertakings on the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida sanctions list. In doing so, it ensures that listed individuals, entities and undertakings have access to fair and clear procedures for the administration of requests for removal (delisting) from the sanctions list.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Office will fairly and expeditiously consider and process all requests for delisting and travel to interview each petitioner in person in the petitioner’s country of residence, whenever possible.

The above-mentioned work is expected to result in informed decision-making by the Committee on the Ombudsperson’s analysis and recommendation on the delisting request contained in a comprehensive report on each case.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, including in the context of information-sharing, the Office cooperates with, among others, Member States, the European Union, academic institutions, think tanks and international law associations.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Office cooperates with, among others, UNDP, OHCHR, the Counter-Terrorism Committee Executive Directorate, the Office of Counter-Terrorism, the Special Rapporteur on the promotion and protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms while countering terrorism, and the Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team pursuant to resolutions 1526 (2004) and 2253 (2015) concerning ISIL (Da’esh), Al-Qaida and the Taliban and associated individuals and entities. In the context of safety and security, information technology security and logistics, the Office cooperates with the Department of Safety and Security, the Office of Information and Communications Technology and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Office;
(b)	The security situation allows the Office to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Fair and expeditious review of delisting requests

In 2024, the Ombudsperson advanced the consideration of all petitions before the Office, which included the presentation of four cases to the Committee, the submission of five comprehensive reports to the Committee and interviews with three petitioners, and the counsels of two petitioners. The Ombudsperson also undertook extensive inquiries and independent research to gather information on each petition, including from Member States and the Monitoring Team. Two new petitions were accepted by the Office in 2024, bringing the total number of accepted petitions since its inception to 111. The above-mentioned work contributed to the Committee receiving comprehensive reports from the Office on time.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure II).
Figure II – Performance measure: number of comprehensive reports received by the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee
Planned result for 2026
Ensuring fair and expeditious review of delisting requests – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Ombudsperson independently reviewed delisting requests of individuals, entities and undertakings on the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida sanctions list, which met the planned target. Furthermore, the Office conducted extensive outreach activities to raise awareness about its work through its engagement with Member States, regional organizations, academic institutions, think tanks and international law associations. In July 2024, the Office published a booklet to raise awareness about its work.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Office was the need to increase awareness about the work and mandate of the Office. In applying the lesson, the Office will further strengthen its outreach efforts, including translating the informational booklet into five other official languages, distributing it to all relevant stakeholders, and informing all listed individuals and entities of the mandate of the Ombudsperson and of the procedure for submitting a delisting request.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure III).
Figure III – Performance measure: number of comprehensive reports received by the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee

text: 10.	Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2713 (2023)

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts pursuant to resolution 2713 (2023) is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the asset freeze, the travel ban, the targeted arms embargo and the territorial arms embargo focused on Al-Shabaab, the charcoal ban and the improvised explosive device components restrictions, as well as for providing information relevant to the designation of individuals and entities. Its mandate is referenced in Security Council resolution 2444 (2018), renewed in subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2776 (2025). The sanctions regime is aimed at supporting the efforts of the Somali authorities to deliver stability and security in Somalia, to prevent any flows of weapons and ammunition to Al-Shabaab and other actors intent on undermining peace and security in Somalia and the region, and to disrupt the activities of Al-Shabaab, including its finances.

On 15 October 2024, following the request by the Security Council in its resolution 2713 (2023), the Secretary-General provided an update (S/2024/751) on progress against each indicator set out in the benchmarks contained in the technical assessment report (S/2022/698), as well as set an additional benchmark related to the safe management of chemical precursors associated with improvised explosive device manufacture and disposal. By its resolution 2776 (2025), the Council requested the Secretary-General to submit by 1 November 2025 a technical assessment regarding the arms embargo targeting Al-Shabaab.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Al-Shabaab, which includes an asset freeze, a travel ban, targeted and territorial arms embargoes, a charcoal ban and improvised explosive device components restrictions.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will provide updated information to the Security Council and the Security Council Committee pursuant to resolution 2713 (2023) concerning Al-Shabaab.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in the context of information-sharing the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others, Member States, INTERPOL, the African Union and the European Union. It also cooperates with the African Union Support and Stabilization Mission in Somalia.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts cooperates with, among others,  the United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia, the United Nations Support Office in Somalia, the United Nations Office at Nairobi, UNODC, other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate, and the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from the Committee’s sanctions list. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Panel cooperates with the Department of Safety and Security and security teams of the United Nations Office at Nairobi, the United Nations Transitional Assistance Mission in Somalia, the United Nations Support Office in Somalia and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced capacity of the Security Council, the Committee and Member States to counter Al-Shabaab financing

In 2024, in its final report (S/2024/748), the Panel assessed that Al-Shabaab continued to sustain a solid financial base through sophisticated business strategies. The Panel reported that Al-Shabaab used both licit and illicit means to generate revenue, including through checkpoints, extortion, forced taxation, and the use of third-party businesses.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 46).
Table 46 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Security Council and Committee received information from the Panel of Experts on the finances of Al-Shabaab, as well as recommendations on how to disrupt them

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced capacity of the Security Council, the Committee and Member States to degrade the threat posed by Al-Shabaab – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the work of the Panel contributed to the implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Al-Shabaab, which met the planned target. Furthermore, in its final report (S/2024/748), the Panel reported on the threat of Al-Shabaab, the threat posed by the ISIL in Somalia, and the reemergence of piracy off the coast of Somalia. The Panel also contributed to an assessment provided to the Security Council and the Committee on weapons and ammunition management by the Government of the Federal Republic of Somalia and by the federal member states. The Panel’s work and the assessment of progress against the weapons and ammunition management benchmarks are expected to contribute to the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Al-Shabaab.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was the need to gain access to and document in a timely manner weapons captured from Al-Shabaab and in the possession of the Government of the Federal Republic of Somalia, the federal member states, and neighbouring countries. In applying the lesson, the Panel will continue to engage and cooperate with the Government of the Federal Republic of Somalia, the federal member states, and the relevant national, regional and international stakeholders, and use databases and subscriptions procured by the United Nations.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 47).

A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts on Haiti is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the travel ban, asset freeze and territorial arms embargo, as well as for providing information relevant to the potential designation of individuals and entities. The mandate is referenced in Security Council resolution 2653 (2022), renewed in subsequent resolutions, including most recently, 2752 (2024).  The sanctions regime is aimed at, but not limited to, supporting the efforts of the Haitian authorities to deliver stability and security in Haiti, to counter gang violence and criminal activities and prevent human rights abuses.

On 1 October 2024, following a request by the Council in its resolution 2700 (2023), the Secretary-General provided the Council with an assessment of the progress achieved on the key benchmarks modified in the same resolution  (S/2024/711). By its resolution 2752 (2024), the Council requested the Secretary-General to provide an update by 1 October 2025 on progress made against the key benchmarks.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Haiti, which includes a travel ban, an asset freeze and a territorial arms embargo.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will provide updated information to the Security Council and the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 2653 (2022) concerning Haiti.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in line with paragraph 22 of resolution 2653 (2022), the Panel of Experts will cooperate with, among others, Member States, in particular neighbouring countries, and regional and subregional organizations, such as the Caribbean Community, including the Eminent Persons Group appointed by the Caribbean Community, the Organization of American States and the multinational security support mission in Haiti.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts will cooperate with, among others, the United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti (BINUH), the Multinational Security Support Mission in Haiti, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from sanctions list, UNODC and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Panel will cooperate with the Department of Safety and Security, BINUH and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Committee members receive information on gang dynamics, arms trafficking and illicit exploitation of natural resources

In 2024, the Panel of Experts submitted interim (S/2024/253) and final (S/2024/704) reports to the Security Council with substantive information on the security situation in Haiti, including gang dynamics, their activities and leadership, and on individuals that met the designation criteria, including those supporting the gangs. The Panel also provided information on arms trafficking into Haiti and recommended, inter alia, strengthening the territorial arms embargo. The Panel also recommended updating the sanctions designation criteria to target individuals or armed groups engaged in activities that destabilize the situation in Haiti through the illicit exploitation or trade of natural resources.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 51).
Table 51 – Performance measure
