children.text: Planned result for 2026
Full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Haiti – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The Panel  contributed to the full implementation of the sanctions regime, which met the planned target. Following the Panel’s recommendations, the Council strengthened the territorial arms embargo and included designation criteria in relation to the illicit exploitation or trade in natural resources. The Panel also provided the Committee with information on individuals who met the designation criteria, following which the Committee added two individuals to its sanctions list.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was that, owing to the volatile security environment in Haiti that prevented the Panel from spending substantial time on the ground, the Panel had to adjust the approach in conducting its investigations. In applying the lesson, the Panel will revise its investigative methodology, while ensuring it meets the highest investigative standards. The Panel will continue working with BINUH and the Department of Safety and Security to implement all necessary security risk mitigation measures.

text: 12.	Office of the Focal Point for Delisting

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the Office of the Focal Point for Delisting derives from Security Council resolution 1730 (2006), in which the Council adopted a delisting procedure and requested the Secretary-General to establish a Focal Point. The mandate was extended in subsequent resolutions 2083 (2012), 2161 (2014) and 2255 (2015) and, most recently, strengthened in resolution 2744 (2024). The Focal Point is mandated to review delisting requests from individuals, groups, undertakings or entities designated on the lists of the sanctions committees established by the Security Council, excluding the sanctions list of the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee which falls under the purview of the Office of the Ombudsperson established pursuant to Security Council resolution 1904 (2009). The Focal Point is also mandated to deal with requests for travel ban and asset freeze exemptions, and communications related to cases of false or mistaken identity and post-delisting challenges, from certain listed individuals or entities.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to provide an independent review of delisting requests submitted by, or on behalf of, an individual, group, undertaking or entity designated on the lists of the sanctions committees established by the Security Council (“the petitioner”), excluding the ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida Sanctions Committee, in accordance with annex I to resolution 2744 (2024).
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Focal Point will carry out the tasks set out in the delisting procedures detailed in annex I to resolution 2744 (2024), which describes the process for information-gathering, dialogue and committee discussion and decision upon receipt of a delisting request, and in other relevant resolutions.

The above-mentioned work is expected to result in strengthened due process of Security Council sanctions, through fair and clear delisting procedures, and timely processing of requests for delisting, travel ban and asset freeze exemptions, and communications related to cases of false or mistaken identity and post-delisting challenges.

With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional and local levels, including in the context of information-sharing, the Focal Point will cooperate with Member States, such as members of the Security Council, and the designating State(s) and State(s) of residence and nationality or incorporation of the petitioners.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Focal Point will cooperate with any relevant sanctions committee’s groups or panels of experts or monitoring teams, as well as any relevant United Nations envoys engaged in negotiations and peace processes relevant to the sanctions. In the context of safety and security, information technology security and logistics, the Focal Point will also cooperate with the Department of Safety and Security, the Office of Information and Communications Technology and UNDP.

To improve the effectiveness of sanctions imposed by United Nations Security Council, the Focal Point will, as requested, engage with the Informal Working Group of the Security Council on General United Nations Security Council Sanctions Issues established by resolution 2744 (2024).
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the mission;
(b)	The security situation allows the mission to conduct missions, as needed;
(c)	Petitioners and other relevant actors are aware of the new delisting procedure outlined in resolution 2744 (2024).
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthen due process by ensuring fairer procedures for petitioners

By resolution 2744 (2024), the Security Council requested the Secretary-General to appoint the Focal Point to implement the strengthened mandate of the mission. The activities in 2024 focused on the recruitment of the Focal Point in coordination with the Office of Legal Affairs and in consultation with the Informal Working Group of the Security Council on General United Nations Security Council Sanctions Issues, on recruitment outreach activities to attract a wide pool of candidates, the review of the sanctions committees’ guidelines and on the establishment of the Office and its operational readiness.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 56).
Table 56 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Informal Working Group received a list of candidates for the position of the Focal Point for its consideration and approval

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Strengthened due process through well-informed decision-making on delisting requests – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

While the Office of the Focal Point for Delisting has been established, the Focal Point could not be appointed by the due date, which did not meet the planned target. In 2024, the Secretariat undertook the recruitment of the Focal Point and presented candidates to the Informal Working Group for its consideration and approval. The Secretariat also conducted outreach activities to Member States, international organizations, and non-governmental organizations providing briefings on the new delisting procedures and recruitment process of the Focal Point. It also informed current petitioners about procedural changes and their right to elect to withdraw their petitions without prejudice and resubmit them for consideration under the revised delisting procedure.

The Focal Point supports sanctions committees in their consideration of delisting requests. Upon receipt of a delisting request, the Focal Point verifies that the petition properly addresses the original designation criteria and engages with petitioners and relevant stakeholders to gather relevant information. The Focal Point then summarizes all relevant information in a confidential comprehensive report articulating the principal arguments in respect of the delisting request. This report assists the relevant committee in its decision-making process, thereby contributing to the strengthening of due process. The Focal Point also submits two biannual reports on the mission’s activities to the Informal Working Group of the Security Council on General United Nations Security Council Sanctions Issues and participates in various international and regional forums to raise awareness about the new delisting procedure.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the mission was the need to prepare outreach activities to disseminate information to the petitioners about the new procedure outlined in annex I of resolution 2744 (2024). In applying the lesson, the mission will conduct briefings to Member States on the new delisting procedure and prepare an informational booklet to be posted on the mission’s website.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 57).

text: 13.	Support to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004) on the non-proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission in support of the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004) is responsible for the provision of substantive, administrative and logistical support to assist the Committee in achieving the aims of the resolution. The mandate derives from Council resolution 1540 (2004) and from its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2663 (2022).

In line with resolution 2663 (2022), where the Security Council extended the Committee’s mandate until 30 November 2032, the mission assists interested Member States in their national implementation efforts through country-specific visits and dialogues, national round tables, workshops and peer reviews, with the objective of building capacity, facilitating technical assistance and identifying and disseminating effective practices for the implementation of resolution 1540 (2004). The mission further supports the activities of the Committee through the organization of regional and subregional workshops on the implementation of the resolution and through country-specific missions and activities, cooperation between international and regional bodies, and the facilitation of outreach and effective partnerships with civil society and the private sector.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to prevent non-State actors from developing, acquiring, manufacturing, possessing, transporting, transferring or using nuclear, chemical or biological weapons and their means of delivery.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

(a)	Facilitate assistance to Member States, upon their request, which includes support for national reviews of the status of implementation of resolution 1540 (2004) and development of national implementation action plans, and capacity-building and awareness-raising activities for  the implementation of resolution 1540 (2004);

(b)	Promote regional cooperation on the implementation of resolution 1540 (2004) by conducting regional and subregional activities, including training for points of contact for resolution 1540 (2004), peer review, and outreach workshops;

(c)	Follow up on the 2022 comprehensive review of the status of implementation of resolution 1540 (2004), conduct activities to raise awareness and support implementation of the outcome of the review, and mobilize resources to effectively support the renewed mandate of the Committee.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced national capacity to implement resolution 1540 (2004);
(b)	An increased number of reports and national implementation action plans submitted to the Committee;
(c)	Increased awareness and visibility of resolution 1540 (2004) and the risks posed by non-State actors acquiring access to weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery;
(d)	Increased cooperation among regional peers in implementing resolution 1540 (2004);
(e)	Successful implementation of the outcome of the 2022 comprehensive review of the status of implementation of resolution 1540 (2004).

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission cooperates with Governments, international, regional and subregional organizations and civil society organizations to raise awareness of the requirements of resolution 1540 (2004) and to facilitate assistance to Member States, upon their request, to build capacity and draft legislation to enhance the implementation of the resolution.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission works closely with other relevant United Nations entities, such as UNODC, the Office of Counter-Terrorism, the United Nations Interregional Crime and Justice Research Institute and IAEA. The mission also cooperates with the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1373 (2001) concerning counter-terrorism and its Executive Directorate, as well as the Security Council Committee pursuant to resolutions 1267 (1999), 1989 (2011) and 2253 (2015) concerning Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Da’esh), Al-Qaida and associated individuals, groups, undertakings and entities, as well as the Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team supporting that Committee.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following assumptions:
(a)	The proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery to non-State actors remains a threat to international peace and security;
(b)	The political environment in the Security Council continues to enable the Committee to reach consensus on the implementation of planned activities;
(c)	Member States continue to cooperate with the Committee;
(d)	Member States will have the need for assistance to implement resolution 1540 (2004).
The mission integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, and is guided by the gender policy of the Office for Disarmament Affairs.

The mission, in support of the Committee, promotes diversity and inclusion and ensures inclusive programming throughout its work, including the inclusion of disability perspectives and other reinforcing factors, such as gender and age. The mission promotes an inclusive work environment that enables all stakeholders to participate fully and effectively in disarmament forums and processes.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened Member States cooperation and engagement in effective assistance collaboration following the Open Briefing on resolution 1540 (2004)

In 2024, the mission successfully convened its first Open Briefing as mandated by resolution 2663 (2022). The briefing enhanced Member States’ awareness of and engagement in the Committee's activities, and facilitated cooperation and sharing of experiences in implementing the resolution.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 61).

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced regional cooperation on implementing resolution 1540 (2004) – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission contributed to providing support to Member States by having conducted 9 regional workshops that promoted a regional approach towards the full implementation of resolution 1540 (2004). This exceeded the planned target of three workshops planned for 2024. These workshops contributed to the high-rate of points of contact appointments and engagement for resolution 1540 (2004) in promoting national implementation efforts.
Lessons learned and planned change

The mission learned that ensuring sustainable implementation requires national ownership and active participation at the national and regional levels. In applying the lesson, the mission will ensure an integrated approach to capacity-building efforts that align national priorities with the objectives of resolution 1540 (2004), expand its partnerships with regional organizations and entities to build synergies, and enhance mechanisms for continuous feedback for improvements of activities.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure IV).

The proposed resource requirements for the mission for 2026 amount to $3532,000 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($959,100) for the continuation of six posts (1 P-5, 2 P-3 and 3 General Service (Other level)), and operational costs ($2,572,900) comprising expert fees ($1,991,800) and travel ($158,600) of the nine experts of the Committee, official travel of the members of the Committee and staff ($124,600), facilities and infrastructure ($228,200), communications and information technology ($55,200), and other supplies, services and equipment ($14,500).

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and level of posts for the mission. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the staff costs for international staff, while a rate of 33.3 per cent has been applied for national staff, on the basis of the actual vacancy rate in March 2025 and the average vacancy rate in 2024 respectively.

The increase in the requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to the increased requirements for expert fees, lower vacancy rate for international staff compared with the rate of 6.7 per cent applied in 2025, and a new requirement for conference costs related to the 1540 Committee Open Consultations. The increase is offset in part by the application of a higher vacancy rate for national staff compared with the rate of 6.7 per cent applied in 2025 and the application of latest ICT standard rates.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,000,000 will be used for activities in support of the implementation of resolution 1540 (2004), including facilitation of the participation of Member States in events relating to the resolution and country-specific activities. The resources will also cover the continuous work of two Regional Coordinators (P-4) stationed in Africa and Asia, along with a Political Affairs Officer (P-3) responsible for project implementation globally.

In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,000,000 are projected to be used to organize or support a number of activities relating to resolution 1540 (2004), including facilitation of the participation of Member States in events relating to the resolution and country-specific activities. The resources will also cover the continuous work of the two Regional Coordinators (P-4) and the Political Affairs Officer (P-3).
A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Counter-Terrorism Committee Executive Directorate is mandated to support the Counter-Terrorism Committee in its work to monitor, promote and facilitate the implementation by Member States of the relevant Security Council resolutions on terrorism. The mandate derives from Council resolution 1373 (2001) and was renewed in its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2617 (2021), which extended the mandate until 31 December 2025. In addition, the United Nations Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy and the 2022 Delhi Declaration on countering the use of new and emerging technologies for terrorist purposes set forth several tasks for the Executive Directorate with respect to facilitating the delivery of technical assistance, assessing the capacities of Member States to counter the use of new and emerging technologies for terrorist purposes, including by developing a set of non-binding guiding principles, compiling good practices,  producing a gaps analysis, and promoting good counter-terrorism practices.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to enhance and consolidate Member States’ counter-terrorism legislation and policies, institutions and operations by ensuring the full and effective implementation by Member States of Security Council resolution 1373 (2001) and other relevant Council resolutions, to inform the efforts of United Nations entities and other implementing agencies to provide related capacity-building and technical assistance and to analyse new and emerging terrorism threats, trends and challenges.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Executive Directorate will:

(a)	Assist Member States in identifying and addressing implementation and capacity gaps in accordance with the requirements of resolution 1373 (2001) and subsequent Security Council resolutions on terrorism, through assessment visits and stocktaking assessment tools such as the electronic detailed implementation survey (e-DIS) and the overview of implementation assessment (OIA), and make technical recommendations to Member States on ways to strengthen their implementation of the relevant resolutions;

(b)	Strengthen effectiveness, timeliness and impact, as well as transparency and inclusivity of  assessments conducted by CTED on behalf of the Committee, including relating to countering the financing of terrorism (CFT) through targeted and focused follow-up visits as complements to its comprehensive assessments, as well as to annual assessments of gaps and areas requiring more action to implement key provisions of  Security Council resolutions relating to CFT  for the purpose of designing targeted technical assistance  by relevant partners;

(c)	Organize follow-up meetings at the Committee level and in other bilateral and multilateral settings to highlight priority technical assistance needs of visited Member States, and to facilitate the delivery of technical assistance;

(d)	Contribute to identifying and assessing emerging issues, trends and developments relating to relevant resolutions and in support of ACTION 23 of the Pact for the Future, Global Digital Compact and Declaration on Future Generations. In this respect, it will prepare and publish analytical materials, reference tools and guidelines and promote Security Council and Committee policy papers, international standards, codes, and effective practices;

(e)	Integrate and promote in CTED’s work the non-binding guiding principles on “Threats posed by the use of unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) for terrorist purposes”; “Preventing, detecting and disrupting the use of new and emerging financial technologies for terrorist purposes”; and Countering the Use of Information and Communications Technologies (ICT) for Terrorist Purposes prepared in accordance with the “Delhi Declaration”.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in the strengthening of Member States’ capacities to:
(a)	Combat terrorism and violent extremism conducive to terrorism, and achieve the full and effective implementation of resolution 1373 (2001) and other relevant resolutions;
(b)	Take action on recommendations in Committee visit reports and other assessments and provide technical assistance and/or share effective practices with other Member States, as appropriate;

(c)	Operationalize their obligations pursuant to resolution 1373 (2001) and other relevant resolutions by facilitating acceptance and understanding of the international effective practices, techniques and tools available to combat terrorism.

With respect to cooperation with other entities, the Executive Directorate cooperates with a wide range of international, regional and subregional organizations such as the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) and  its regional bodies,)  Organization of Islamic Cooperation, the Council of Europe, the European Union, and the Regional Anti-Terrorist Structure of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization  to raise awareness of international requirements on counter-terrorism at the national and regional levels. It leverages and diversifies its Global Counter-Terrorism Research Network to convene policymakers and researchers, and engages and enhances its partnerships with civil society organizations, think tanks, academic organizations and the private sector to assist the Committee in identifying national, regional and thematic challenges, and developments.

With respect to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Executive Directorate works closely with other United Nations entities, within the framework of the United Nations Global Counter-Terrorism Coordination Compact. CTED enhanced its efficiency by chairing or co-chairing Global Compact working groups and by sharing the Committee’s recommendations and consented reports with the Compact.  The Executive Directorate will continue to collaborate with the Office of Counter-Terrorism and UNODC on relevant issues. It works closely with other subsidiary bodies of the Security Council and their expert groups to enhance information-sharing. It maintains strong cooperation with OHCHR and the Special Rapporteur on the promotion and protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms while countering terrorism.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Consent of Member States to receive assessment visits and subsequently brief the Committee on progress made in implementing Committee recommendations:
(b)	Ability to organize and conduct visits in accordance with United Nations safety and security measures;
(c)	Participation of technical experts from international and regional organizations in country visit assessments conducted by CTED on behalf of the Committee;
(d)	Commitment of implementing partners to deliver technical assistance pursuant to Committee findings;
(e)	The Counter-Terrorism Committee adopts the Non-Binding Guiding Principles for Countering the Use of ICTs for Terrorist Purpose.

The Executive Directorate integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, and works with the   Counter-Terrorism Coordination Compact Working Group on Adopting a Gender-Sensitive Approach to Preventing and Countering Terrorism.
Programme performance in 2024
Roadmaps to improve the capacity of Member States to counter terrorism and violent extremism conducive to terrorism

In 2024, the Committee adopted reports on visits to seven States (Chile, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Latvia, the Republic of Korea, Spain, Thailand and Uzbekistan). CTED completed eight OIAs and e-DISs, and 26 capacity-building workshops, meetings, consultations and activities. CTED also facilitated technical assistance and developed 11 roadmaps for select beneficiaries (Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Kyrgyzstan, Mauritania, Senegal, Cambodia, Costa Rica, Gabon and Guatemala) as part of several capacity-building programs spearheaded by UNOCT to enhance Member States’ compliance with relevant Security Council resolutions and international standards. Based on the roadmaps, beneficiaries developed legislative, operational, and technological measures to operationalize API and PNR systems. Authorities in Senegal utilized a roadmap developed by CTED to better address the threat posed by UAS for terrorist purposes, including through enhanced data gathering on the threat, amended legislative and regulatory frameworks relevant to UAS, and enhanced information exchange mechanisms. These roadmaps also served as blueprints for other partners to tailor future capacity-building assistance.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure V).
Figure V – Performance measure: number of Member States adopting national roadmaps to counter terrorism and violent extremism conducive to terrorism
Planned results for 2026

Result 1: Member States utilize CTED assessments and analysis to identify and respond to terrorism threats, trends and challenges to better implement resolution 1373 (2001) and subsequent Security Council resolutions – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

CTED contributed to the identification of counter-terrorism trends including through the production of 5 publications. The planned target of 10 publications was missed due to a combination of factors including inadequate staffing. The Executive Directorate did, however, provide advice on several thematic areas such as border control and law enforcement, human rights and CFT, including promotion of the non-binding guiding principles on threats posed by UAS for terrorist purposes.

In 2026, the Executive Directorate aims to develop 10 publications to promote international standards and good practices. CTED will further enhance use of its OIA and e-DIS data to identify emerging trends and issue technical guidance.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure VI).

Figure VI – Performance measure: Member States examine their own national counter-terrorism measures in light of updated technical materials and guidance on the implementation of relevant Security Council resolutions
Result 2: Member States have access to strengthened assessment reports with action-orientated recommendations – Proposed programme plan for 2026

The Committee agreed in August 2024 on actions to strengthen the assessment process regarding effectiveness, timeliness, inclusivity and transparency.  Since then, a greater number of Member States have: (I) provided written feedback on steps taken to implement the Committee’s recommendations; (II) attended that portion of the Committee session at which its PAO is presented; and (III) provided oral briefings to the Committee at its plenaries.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for CTED was the need to further improve its methodology to enhance the effectiveness, timeliness and impact of its assessments.  In applying the lesson, CTED will, inter alia, frame recommendations in assessments to make them more actionable: share a matrix of technical assistance needs with potential donors and implementing agencies, upon approval by the visited Member State; and request Member State’s feedback on steps taken to implement recommendations within 12 months of receiving the final report.

Extrabudgetary resources

text: 15.	United Nations Investigative Team to Promote Accountability for Crimes Committed by Da’esh/Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant

children.text: Liquidation activities

The mandate of the United Nations Investigative Team to Promote Accountability for Crimes Committed by Da’esh/Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (UNITAD) was defined in Security Council resolution 2379 (2017) and extended in subsequent resolutions of the Council. In its resolution 2697 (2023), the Council, at the request of the Government of Iraq, decided to extend the mandate of UNITAD until 17 September 2024 only.
The administrative liquidation of UNITAD, including the disposal of assets, was carried out from 18 September to 31 December 2024, and was facilitated by UNAMI.

The General Assembly, by its resolution 78/253, appropriated the amount of $25.7 million for 2024.  UNITAD incurred $20.0 million in expenditure for the period, representing a resource utilization rate of 78 per cent, as result of the closure of the mission in September while provision was made in the budget for a 12-month period.
Table 68 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)

The process for the drawdown and liquidation of property of UNITAD was guided by the principles of and policies contained in Financial Rule 105.23. The assets of UNITAD, with a total capitalized value/acquisition value of $12,304,751 (corresponding net book value/operational value of $5,350,308), were disposed of as at 31 December 2024, of which 96.7 per cent have been transferred to UNAMI, UNSOS and UNMISS, while the rest were written off or sold locally.

text: Annex I  Summary of follow-up action taken to implement the decisions and requests made by the General Assembly, including the requests and recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions endorsed by the Assembly

table_content.text: Action taken to implement the recommendation
Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (A/79/7/Add.3 and A/79/7/Add.20)
Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (A/79/7/Add.3 and A/79/7/Add.20)

The Advisory Committee notes that the sanctions regime pursuant to Security Council resolution 1718 (2006) is supported exclusively by the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006). Taking into consideration the anticipated workload and complexity of the sanctions regime, the Committee recommends that the General Assembly request the Secretary-General to conduct an evaluation of the support arrangements for the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1718 (2006), including capacities within the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, and that information thereon be provided in future budget reports. (para. 11)

Taking into the complexity of this sanctions regime, as detailed in paragraphs 43-45, the significantly increased workload of the Mission, and upon completion of evaluation of the current support arrangement, the Secretariat assesses that the Department lacked the in-house capacity to provide the support required by the 1718 Sanctions Committee and its Chair. Consequently, the Secretariat concludes the existing support arrangement through the established special political mission remains appropriate and adequate.

The Advisory Committee trusts that updated information on the recruitment status of vacant positions will be provided to the General Assembly during the consideration of the present report and in the next budget submission. (para. 14)

Missions under cluster II make concerted efforts to recruit and fill vacant posts in accordance with the staff selection policy. Recruitment exercises, however, may be affected and delayed by external factors, including visa restrictions, availability of qualified candidates in the duty stations and temporary hiring restrictions in efforts to mitigate financial challenges facing the Organization that have an adverse impact on the missions’ ability to fill vacant posts. Despite these challenges, missions remain committed to fill all current and future vacancies as expeditiously as possible.

The Advisory Committee trusts that efforts will be made to achieve a more equitable geographical representation of Member States among the civilian staff and experts in thematic cluster II and that updated information thereon will be included in all future budget submissions. The Advisory Committee makes further observations on geographical representation in its main report on estimates in respect of special political missions (A/79/7/Add.1). (para. 24)

The Secretariat is committed to advancing equitable geographical representation in geographical posts and recruiting staff on as wide a geographical basis as possible for all nongeographical posts in accordance with Article 101.3 of the Charter. The intention going forward is to fill future vacant geographical posts as set forth in the Secretary-General's administrative instruction (ST/AI/2010/3/Rev.3), including making every effort to select candidates from un/under-represented member states, particularly from outside the organization. In this connection, at an organizational level, the Secretariat continues to take measures to progress on this important mandate including targeted talent outreach, purposeful partnerships with Member States and the Resident Coordinators and UN Information Centres and overhauling the staff selection process to ensure it is effective, efficient, fair and inclusive. To this end, DPPA nominated a D-1 staff member to join the UN Advisory Board on Purposeful Partnerships to contribute to the implementation of the “Purposeful partnership” arrangement between the Secretariat and Member States and help build talent pipelines that have become essential in identifying and attracting potential candidates from underrepresented Member States proactively. 
To achieve a more equitable geographical representation among consultants working as Security Council sanctions experts, the Secretariat organized outreach events (in-person or hybrid format) for Member States and UN regional groups to promote applications from those groups.

The Advisory Committee trusts that efforts will continue to be made to improve the gender balance of the civilian staff and experts under thematic cluster II entities and that updated information regarding gender representation and the related recruitment efforts will be provided in the context of all future budget submissions. The Advisory Committee makes further observations on gender balance in its main report on estimates in respect of special political missions (A/79/7/Add.1). (para. 25)

To enhance gender balance, missions within cluster II have taken steps to integrate gender perspectives into their operational activities and have actively engaged in virtual career fairs aimed at specific regions and demographic groups for both staff and experts, as detailed in paragraphs 6 and 7 above.
The Advisory Committee takes note of the pending review of the rates for experts and trusts that that updated information will be provided in the next budget report (see also A/78/7/Add.3, para. 18).
The review of experts’ rates was finalized in December 2024, with the updated rates applied to all new contracts effective 17 January 2025 and reflected in 2026 budget submission.

The Advisory Committee, without prejudice to the independence of the Focal Point for Delisting, encourages coordination with the Office of the Ombudsperson established pursuant to resolution 1904 (2009) to seek efficiencies and synergies in the performance of administrative duties and research support and trusts that the Secretary-General will report thereon in the next budget submission. (para. 14)

The Secretariat considered that seeking efficiencies and synergies in the performance of administrative duties and research support between the Ombudsperson’s and the Focal Point’s Offices could blur operational boundaries, thereby increasing the risk of compromising their independence, impartiality and the handling of sensitive or confidential information. To maintain both Offices’ independence, impartiality, and stringent confidentiality requirements, it is essential to maintain a clear distinction between the two Offices, each supported by its own dedicated staff. These requirements are fundamental to the credibility and effectiveness of both Offices and to upholding the standards for due process.
